div1.head: The Clinic Bulletin, November 30, 1940
div1.p:
LECTURES
----
Monday, December 2, Dr. Brunsting--Drug eruptions.
Friday, December 6, Dr. Kierland--Cutaneous mani-
festations of allergy.
Monday, December 9, Dr. Alvarez--Food sensitive-
ness.
Friday, December 13, Dr. H. L. Williams--Allergy
in rhinologic practice.
Friday, December 20, Dr. Faber--Endometrial biopsy
and sterility.
Monday, December 23, Dr. L. M. Randall--Manage-
ment of pelvic inflammatory disease.
Friday, December 27, Dr. Hunt--Gynecologic office
procedures.
Monday, December 30, Dr. Counseller--Surgical in-
dications in the treatment of malignancy of the
female generative tract.

These lectures will be held at 7:30 p.m. in the
Assembly Room. Visiting physicians are invited to
attend.
SEMINARS

The biochemistry seminar will be held Monday
at 5:00 p.m. in the Assembly Room. The topic is
“Chemical changes in the blood and their clinical
significance” and the essayist, Dr. Osterberg.

The following seminars will be held Tuesday at
7:30 p.m. at Mayo Foundation House:
Seminar in anesthesia.--The topic is “Physiology of
circulation” and the essayist, Dr. Barrett.
Seminar in clinical physiology.--The topic is “Hepatic
dysfunction: pathologic physiology of the liver”
and the essayist, Dr. J. W. Gardner.
Seminar in clinical medicine.--The topic is “Gastritis,
its classification, symptomatology, significance and
treatment” and the essayist, Dr. J. R. Miller.
Seminar in physical medicine.--The topic is “Massage
in relation to internal medicine” and the essayist,
Dr. McLoughlin.
Surgical seminar.--The topics are “Physiology of res-
piration” and “Postoperative atelectasis and ab-
scess.” The essayists are, respectively, Drs. Svien
and Howe; the chairman is Dr. Ferris.
Urologic seminar.--The topic is “The etiology of the
urinary calculi.” The essayists are Drs. Jacobson
and Schulte.
CLINICAL SOCIETY MEETING

There will be a meeting of the Clinical Society
at Mayo Foundation House on Thursday, December 5,
at 6 p.m. A buffet supper will be served followed
by a short business meeting. At 7:45 o'clock Dr.
Hench will give an illustrated talk on “The story of
yellow fever--some new historical discoveries.” Dr.
Hench has recently visited the scene of the epoch-
making experiments on the transmission of yellow
fever. Members of the staff, their wives, and friends
are invited to the lecture.
NOTICE

Because of confusion caused by consultants quoting
prices of hospital rooms to patients, it is requested
that any discussion of costs be left to the Hospital
Assignment Desk. Consultants are also requested to
allow the Hospital Assignment Desk to fix the hour
of the patient's arrival at the hospital.
MEETING OF ASSOCIATION OF FELLOWS

The annual meeting of the Association of Fellows
will be held at 9:00 p.m. Tuesday, December 3, at
Mayo Foundation House. Election of officers will
be held and new proposals for hospitals benefits will
be presented. All fellows are urged to attend the
meeting.

CHRISTMAS SALE OF ARTICLES BY THE
OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY DEPARTMENT

The Christmas sale of articles by the Occupational
Therapy Department will open at 10:00 a.m. Wednes-
day, December 4, in the Kahler lobby and will con-
tinue until 6:00 p.m. Candy will also be sold.

CHRISTMAS PARTY AT MAYO CLINIC
WOMEN'S CLUB

A Christmas party will be held Wednesday eve-
ning, December 4, at the Mayo Clinic Women's Club.
Donations of cash or merchandise from members
will be appreciated for the boxes which will be dis-
tributed among the needy for Christmas.
PERSONALS

Dr. Alvarez will deliver a Max Ballin lecture at
the North End Clinic in Detroit Wednesday, Decem-
ber 4. His subject is “Recent advances in the treat-
ment of food allergy.”

Dr. Camp has left for Cleveland where he will
address a meeting of the Radiological Society of
North America. His subject is “Pseudofractures in
diseases affecting the skeletal system”; he will also
give an instruction course on “Contrast myelography.”

Drs. Bowing and Popp will also address the meet-
ing of the Radiological Society of North America in
Cleveland next week. Their subjects are, respective-
ly, “Polyps and polypoid malignant disease of the
rectum and rectosigmoid treated with radium,” and
“Roentgén therapy for chronic macrolymphocytic
and mesolymphocytic lymphatic leukemia.”

Dr. Walters will address the Academy of Medicine
in Toronto, Ontario, Tuesday. His subject is “Lesions
of the biliary tract.”

Dr. Buie will be in Sioux Falls, South Dakota,
Tuesday to address a meeting of the Sioux Valley
Medical Society. His subject is “Fundamental facts
concerning proctologic problems.”
(continued on other side)

Dr. Helmholz will attend a meeting of the Advisory
Committee of the White House Conference on Chil-
dren in a Democracy, in Washington, D. C., the first
part of the week.
